author: slessard
body:
Get-Help for the Get-Content commandlet erroneously reports that one of the valid values for the -Encoding parameter is "byte" but if you try to use byte you get an exception stating `Cannot bind parameter 'Encoding'. Cannot convert the "byte" value of type "System.String" to type "System.Text.Encoding".`

Steps to reproduce
------------------

```
Get-Help Get-Content
```
the output includes:

```
SYNTAX
    Get-Content ... [-Encoding {Unknown | String | Unicode | Byte | BigEndianUnicode | UTF8 | UTF7 | UTF32 | Ascii | Default | Oem}] 
```
then execute the commandlet as follows:

```
PS > Get-Content -Encoding byte /etc/var/hosts
Get-Content : Cannot bind parameter 'Encoding'. Cannot convert the "byte" value of type "System.String" to type "System.Text.Encoding".
At line:1 char:23
+ Get-Content -Encoding byte /etc/var/hosts
+                       ~~~~
+ CategoryInfo          : InvalidArgument: (:) [Get-Content], ParameterBindingException
+ FullyQualifiedErrorId : CannotConvertArgumentNoMessage,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.GetContentCommand
 

```

Expected behavior
-----------------
Get-Help for Get-Content does NOT report "byte" as a valid value for the -Encoding switch


Actual behavior
---------------
Get-Help for Get-Content incorrectly says "byte" IS a valid value for the -Encoding switch

```
SYNTAX
    Get-Content [-Path] <String[]> [-ReadCount <Int64>] [-TotalCount <Int64>] [-Tail <Int32>] [-Filter <String>] [-Include <String[]>] [-Exclude <String[]>] [-Force] [-Credential <PSCredential>] [-Delimiter <String>] [-Wait] [-Raw] 
    [-Encoding {Unknown | String | Unicode | Byte | BigEndianUnicode | UTF8 | UTF7 | UTF32 | Ascii | Default | Oem}] [-Stream <String>] [-AsByteStream] [<CommonParameters>]

```

Environment data
----------------

```
> $PSVersionTable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.1.0
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    6.1.0
OS                             Darwin 16.7.0 Darwin Kernel Version 16.7.0: Wed Oct 10 20:06:00 PDT 2018; root:xnu-3789.73.24~1/RELEASE_X86_64
Platform                       Unix
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0

```

comments.author: Halkcyon
comments.body: This is a carry-over from Windows PowerShell's documentation where `Byte` is a valid argument, but it looks like in PowerShell Core, it expects an `Encoding` *object* instead.  I was able to re-produce this in `6.*`, but not `5.1`.  I think it might be a defect for the `Get-Content` cmdlet rather than a wrong help doc.

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
@slessard: On a general note, please report problems with the documentation at https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell-Docs/issues.

`-Encoding Byte` was replaced with switch `-AsByteStream`, given that raw bytes aren't really an encoding  (see #7986).

The online documentation already reflects this change - https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.management/get-content?view=powershell-6#optional-parameters

Be sure to run `Update-Help` to update your local copies of the help topics as well.

After doing that, the `Byte` enumeration value is gone:

```powershell
 [-Encoding {A `System.Text.Encoding` object | ASCII | BigEndianUnicode | OEM |
    String | Unicode | UTF7 | UTF8 | UTF8BOM | UF8NoBOM | UTF32 | Unknown}]
```

The somewhat cryptic representation confirms what  @TheIncorrigible1 stated: in addition to the enumeration values you can now also pass `System.TextEncoding` instances directly to `-Encoding` (but, as stated, for byte streams, use `-AsByteStream`; to get a byte array as a _single object_, add `-Raw`).
